entry.title: Regarding Prefilling Customer Data in Emarsys Forms
entry.content:
Hi Team,

 

I’d like to check if it’s possible to prefill customer data into Emarsys Forms, so that customers don’t have to manually enter their information.

Could you please confirm if this functionality is supported and advise on how it can be implemented?

 

Thank you in advance.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Regarding Prefilling Customer Data in Emarsys Forms
entry.content:
Hi,

 

This can be done by following the steps below based on KBA 3530893 - How to prefill Change Profile form with contact master data? - SAP for Me:

 

You can insert form link in follow format into email content, then this form will be prefilled with contact master data in Emarsys if contact opens it from inbox email.

https://<form link domain>/u/register.php?par={{contact.uid}}_$cid$_$llid$_1_t_<account id>_<form id>

 

You need to replace <form link domain>, <account id> and <form id> parts of URL in Cause part. And you can get them from form preview.

For example, following URL is the form preview one:

https://goto.lifestylelabels.com/u/register.php?CID=213802546&session_id=33c5Wc7kCY1k37121887&f=100005987

Then the mapping is like:

  • <form link domain> -> "goto.lifestylelabels.com"
  • <account id> -> "213802546"
  • <form id> -> "100005987"

You can get the URL to be used in Email content:

https://goto.lifestylelabels.com/u/register.php?par={{contact.uid}}_$cid$_$llid$_1_t_213802546_100005987

 

Best regards,

SAP Technical Support

entry.title: How to replace LOOP AT itab... AT NEW/END OF by a modern ABAP 7.40 construct
entry.content:
I'd like to use ABAP 7.40 instead of the old AT NEW and AT END OF statements, because the latter are prone to errors if LOOP AT...INTO is used as some fields can be changed to all *, or because the components of the control break must be positioned to the left to the internal table otherwise the result is wrong.

Here is the original code to convert to ABAP 7.40:

TYPES:
  BEGIN OF ty_itab_line,
    carrid TYPE sbook-carrid,
    connid TYPE sbook-connid,
    fldate TYPE sbook-fldate,
    bookid TYPE sbook-bookid,
  END OF ty_itab_line.
TYPES tt_itab TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_itab_line WITH EMPTY KEY.
DATA(itab) = VALUE tt_itab( carrid = 'LH'
                            connid = '0370'
                            fldate = sy-datum
                            ( bookid = 1 )
                            ( bookid = 2 ) ).
DATA(log) = VALUE string_table( ).
SORT itab BY carrid connid fldate.
LOOP AT itab ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<line>).
  AT NEW connid.
    INSERT |Flight { <line>-carrid }{ <line>-connid } { <line>-fldate }| INTO TABLE log.
    DATA(number_of_bookings) = 0.
  ENDAT.
  INSERT |  - Booking { <line>-bookid }| INTO TABLE log.
  number_of_bookings = number_of_bookings + 1.
  AT END OF carrid.
    INSERT |  - Number of bookings for flight { <line>-carrid }{ <line>-connid
           } { <line>-fldate }: { number_of_bookings }| INTO TABLE log.
  ENDAT.
ENDLOOP.

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: How to replace LOOP AT itab... AT NEW/END OF by a modern ABAP 7.40 construct
entry.content:
The workaround is to use LOOP AT...GROUP BY instead of the AT control level statements (since ABAP 7.40):

TYPES:
  BEGIN OF ty_itab_line,
    carrid TYPE sbook-carrid,
    connid TYPE sbook-connid,
    fldate TYPE sbook-fldate,
    bookid TYPE sbook-bookid,
  END OF ty_itab_line.
TYPES tt_itab TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_itab_line WITH EMPTY KEY.
DATA(itab) = VALUE tt_itab( carrid = 'LH'
                            connid = '0370'
                            fldate = sy-datum
                            ( bookid = 1 )
                            ( bookid = 2 ) ).
DATA(log) = VALUE string_table( ).
SORT itab BY carrid connid fldate.
LOOP AT itab
     ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<line>)
     GROUP BY ( carrid = <line>-carrid
                connid = <line>-connid
                fldate = <line>-fldate )
     ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<group_key>).
  INSERT |Flight { <group_key>-carrid }{ <group_key>-connid } { <group_key>-fldate }| INTO TABLE log.
  DATA(number_of_bookings) = 0.
  LOOP AT GROUP <group_key> ASSIGNING <line>.
    INSERT |  - Booking { <line>-bookid }| INTO TABLE log.
    number_of_bookings = number_of_bookings + 1.
  ENDLOOP.
  INSERT |  - Number of bookings for flight { <group_key>-carrid }{ <group_key>-connid
         } { <group_key>-fldate }: { number_of_bookings }| INTO TABLE log.
ENDLOOP.

Happy grouping!

entry.title: How to suppress the ATC error "Do not modify table rows in tables with control level processing"
entry.content:
I get the ATC error "Do not modify table rows in tables with control level processing" because of the line 18. I'm changing the field SMOKER for further processing after ENDLOOP:

TYPES:
  BEGIN OF ty_itab_line,
    carrid TYPE sbook-carrid,
    connid TYPE sbook-connid,
    fldate TYPE sbook-fldate,
    bookid TYPE sbook-bookid,
    smoker TYPE sbook-smoker,
  END OF ty_itab_line.
TYPES tt_itab TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_itab_line WITH EMPTY KEY.
DATA(itab) = VALUE tt_itab( carrid = 'LH'
                            connid = '0370'
                            fldate = sy-datum
                            ( bookid = 1 smoker = abap_true )
                            ( bookid = 2 smoker = abap_false ) ).
DATA(log) = VALUE string_table( ).
SORT itab BY carrid connid fldate.
LOOP AT itab ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<line>).
  AT NEW connid.
    INSERT |Flight { <line>-carrid }{ <line>-connid } { <line>-fldate }| INTO TABLE log.
    DATA(number_of_bookings) = 0.
  ENDAT.
  <line>-smoker = abap_false.
  INSERT |  - Booking { <line>-bookid }| INTO TABLE log.
  number_of_bookings = number_of_bookings + 1.
  AT END OF carrid.
    INSERT |  - Number of bookings for flight { <line>-carrid }{ <line>-connid
           } { <line>-fldate }: { number_of_bookings }| INTO TABLE log.
  ENDAT.
ENDLOOP.

 

There is no pseudo-comment and no pragma. The only solution is to request an exemption.

How to get rid of this message?

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: IF_RAP_QUERY_PROVIDER~SELECT called two times causing...

entry.title: Re: How to suppress the ATC error "Do not modify table rows in tables with control level proces
entry.content:
For this situation, the SAP extended check is simplistic, it can't know if it's a problem or not. As far as I know, it could be a problem only if the field changed is either CARRID and CONNID because the control level logic might be disturbed, but I don't see any problem with the other fields.

The main problem is the absence of pseudo-comment (or pragma) to let the developer confirm that there's no issue.

The workaround is to use LOOP AT GROUP BY instead of the AT control level statements (since ABAP 7.40):

TYPES:
  BEGIN OF ty_itab_line,
    carrid TYPE sbook-carrid,
    connid TYPE sbook-connid,
    fldate TYPE sbook-fldate,
    bookid TYPE sbook-bookid,
    smoker TYPE sbook-smoker,
  END OF ty_itab_line.
TYPES tt_itab TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_itab_line WITH EMPTY KEY.
DATA(itab) = VALUE tt_itab( carrid = 'LH'
                            connid = '0370'
                            fldate = sy-datum
                            ( bookid = 1 smoker = abap_true )
                            ( bookid = 2 smoker = abap_false ) ).
DATA(log) = VALUE string_table( ).
SORT itab BY carrid connid fldate.
LOOP AT itab
     ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<line>)
     GROUP BY ( carrid = <line>-carrid
                connid = <line>-connid
                fldate = <line>-fldate )
     ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<group_key>).
  INSERT |Flight { <group_key>-carrid }{ <group_key>-connid } { <group_key>-fldate }| INTO TABLE log.
  DATA(number_of_bookings) = 0.
  LOOP AT GROUP <group_key> ASSIGNING <line>.
    <line>-smoker = abap_false.
    INSERT |  - Booking { <line>-bookid }| INTO TABLE log.
    number_of_bookings = number_of_bookings + 1.
  ENDLOOP.
  INSERT |  - Number of bookings for flight { <group_key>-carrid }{ <group_key>-connid
         } { <group_key>-fldate }: { number_of_bookings }| INTO TABLE log.
ENDLOOP.

entry.content:
Hi Mircea,

I doubt that this is still an issue for you since it has been almost 1 year. However, I wanted to provide an answer. First, it makes more sense to replace the descriptions with the new values or to delete the templates rather than blank out the descriptions completely. Having said that, you can put HTML code such as a "BR" tag <br> or a "P" tag <p> in the description field of your CSV file to blank out the current value upon upload.

entry.title: SAP Fieldglass CDET E2E Provisioning and Setup guide
entry.content:
Introducing the CDET Strategy

The CDET program aims to re-imagine and improve the deployment experience through automation and self-service, allowing you to achieve faster time to value while minimizing the efforts. In this blog post, we’ll guide you through the enhanced self-service deployment. You’ll learn how to request your test and production environments with the Self-Provisioning process, import and move your configs with the Configuration Mover, and use the Comparison Tool to audit your configured production environment.

 

(SAP Fieldglass CDET E2E How-to video)

Creating the Provisioning Request

To request your SAP Fieldglass environment using the newly designed self-provisioning process, follow below steps: 

  1. Access SAP for Me 
  2. Click Systems & Provisioning on the left-hand menu, under Dashboards
  3. Select the Provisioning tab 
  4. Choose the desired SAP Fieldglass product on SAP Systems and select Start Provisioning 
  5. Choose a Data Center from the dropdown list 
  6. Select Submit 

After submitting your provisioning request, the IT Client Contact receives two emails from SAP Fieldglass: One with the Registration Code and a Welcome email . To proceed with the tenant provisioning:

  1. Copy the code from the Registration Code email  
  2. Open the Click Here link in the Welcome email  
  3. Paste the copied code into the Registration Code field  
  4. Select Continue  
  5. Enter a unique buyer code (2-6 characters) in the Buyer Code field or select Check Availability to choose one of the suggested codes 
  6. Select Register  

 Finishing the provisioning process, the IT contact receives three emails:  

  • An activation Information email for SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) 
  • A registration confirmation email with the selected Buyer Code and a link to the production tenant (SSO) 
  • A password reset email for accessing the Test tenant.

Creating a Configuration Manager User 

After successfully accessing your test environment, it’s time to start configuring it. The first step is to create a Configuration Manager user to manage your SAP Fieldglass environment and use the available self-service tools. 

Create a Configuration Manager user following these steps: 

  1. Go to the Admin Configuration page by clicking on the gear icon 
  2. Click User  on the User Panel 
  3. Click directly on top of your User Name  
  4. Select option Create Configuration Manager   
  5. Return to the User List and see your newly created user on the list

Pulling Configurations from a Leading Practice Environment 

SAP Fieldglass Leading Practice environments represent structured templates that aim to accelerate your deployment. They are tenants with pre-defined Company Configurations, Admin Configurations, and Company Structure Objects that can be used when moving configurations with Configuration Mover. 

The Leading Practice Environments act as the Source Environment from where the Configuration Mover replicates the configurations to your target test environment, ensuring consistency and reliability throughout the process. 

After defining which Leading Practice Environment best suits you, follow these steps: 

  1. Sign in as Configuration Manager User to your Target Environment 
  2. Select the Configuration Mover tile  
  3. Read and then accept the end user acknowledgment   
  4. Select YES for the question - “Do you want to pull configuration from an SAP Fieldglass Leading Practice Solution?”  
  5. Choose a Leading Practice environment as Source 
  6. Select the appropriate connector pairs to be used to build the Target Environment  
  7. Select Continue   
  8. Review all selections and choose Submit   
  9. Read and Accept the End User Acknowledgment   
  10. Choose Submit 

The background job starts running and the Configuration Mover audit trail is displayed, where you can check the statuses of the moved data. 

Editing Company Configurations 

Change company configurations as you see fit by following these instructions: 

  1. Select the Company Configuration tile, from the Configuration Manager Dashboard 
  2. Click Edit  
  3. Scroll through the configuration list, or search for the desired configuration, and make the necessary updates 
  4. Save your changes 
  5. Enter a Reason for the change 
  6. Select Save 

Moving Configuration Between Environments 

Once your test environment is completely configured and tested, it's time to move all Admin, Company and Site configurations to the production environment. 

Use the Configuration Mover to quickly copy all configurations with the following instructions: 

  1. Sign in as the Configuration Manager user to the Target Environment  
  2. Select the Configuration Mover tile, from the Configuration Manager dashboard
  3. Select NO for the question - “Do you want to pull configuration from an SAP Fieldglass Leading Practice Solution?”  
  4. Enter the source environments details (URL, Buyer Code, Username and Password)  
  5. Select the appropriate connector pairs to be used to build your target environment 
  6. Select Continue   
  7. Review all the selections and choose Submit   
  8. Read and accept the End User Acknowledgment  
  9. Choose Submit 

The background job starts running and the Configuration Mover audit trail is displayed, where you can check the statuses of the moved data. 

Using the Comparison Tool 

Whether you need to verify if your test and production environments match or check for unwanted changes prior to moving your data objects, the Comparison Tool can expose side-by-side the existing differences between 2 environment’s company and site configurations. 

To compare environments, follow below instructions: 

  1. Sign in as the Configuration Manager user to the target environment  
  2. Select the Comparison Tool tile, from the Configuration Manager dashboard
  3. Select NO for the question - “Do you want to pull configuration from an SAP Fieldglass Leading Practice Solution?”  
  4. Enter the source environments details (URL, Buyer Code, Username and Password)  
  5. Select Compare  

The differences between environments are presented side-by-side in two separate tabs: Company Configurations and Site Configurations, and you can export the list in .csv format. If no differences are found, a message will appear on the top of the screen. 

See Also 

  • SAP Fieldglass Configuration Mover learning journey 
  • Contingent and services procurement certifications 
  • SAP Help documentation
  • Onboarding resource center 
  • SAP Fieldglass - Configuration Mover Leading Practices 
  • SAP Fieldglass - Gold Environment Configurations 
  • SAP Fieldglass - Configuration Mover How-to 
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/spend-management-blog-posts-by-sap/save-time-and-cut-complexity-manage-sap-fieldglass-configurations-with/ba-p/14247696

entry.title: Re: Unable to Create/Post STO Purchase order Using BO/API
entry.content:
Hello @AnuradhaDwivedi,

What’s causing the error

Message: APPL_MM_PUR_PO 065 – Use a supported purchase order item category for the item & Why: The Purchase Order OData V4 API (API_PURCHASEORDER_2) does not support STO item category U (internal 7). Passing PurchaseOrderItemCategory: 7 triggers this error. SAP limits this API to standard NB POs and a small set of item categories. SAP Help Portal-APIs for Sourcing and Procurement-Purchase Order (OData V4)

Supported via the PO API include Standard (blank), Consignment (K), Subcontracting (L), Third-Party (S), and Enhanced Limits (A/E). Note that STO is not included in this list. SAP Help Portal

The correct approach for STO

Use the Stock Transport Order API instead of API_PURCHASEORDER_2:

  • API: sap-s4-CE_STOCKTRANSPORTORDER_0001 for Public Cloud purpose built to create STOs. SAP Business Accelerator Hub

If you insist on the PO API, you must change your scenario to a standard NB PO and remove item category U/7. By design, it still won’t be an STO and will have no Shipping tab.

SAP Support Portal-3555741 - Cannot create/update Purchase Order NB2 using API_PURCHASEORDER_2

KBAs and useful documentation

  • 3110493 – Cannot create Intercompany Stock Transfer Orders via Purchase Order API. States the PO API only creates standard NB POs; STO is not supported. SAP Support Portal-3110493 - Cannot create Purchase Order for Intercompany Stock Transfer Using API : API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseOrder
  • 3555741 – API_PURCHASEORDER_2 supports only Standard NB and ZNB types derived from NB (confirms scope). SAP Support Portal-3555741 - Cannot create/update Purchase Order NB2 using API_PURCHASEORDER_2
  • SAP Help – Purchase Order (OData V4): lists the supported item categories for the service; STO category U/7 isn’t included. SAP Help Portal

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: RunMyJobs in RISE with SAP: SAP ECS managed services in the RISE reference architecture
entry.content:
RunMyJobs in RISE with SAP: SAP ECS managed services in the RISE reference architecture

 

RISE with SAP provides a standardized framework for moving on-premises enterprise workloads into a managed cloud operating model. A RISE transformation brings integrated tools, a proven methodology and managed services to simplify modernization and accelerate digital transformation. SAP Enterprise Cloud Services (ECS) is central to this model, operating the technical foundation and delivering select managed services.

 

From my vantage point as SVP of ISV Partner Management at SAP, this is closely tied to how our ecosystem of partner solutions, and RunMyJobs by Redwood in particular, continues to evolve and create value.

 

I’ll explain here how this solution fits into the RISE reference architecture through ECS-managed services — and why it’s critical for SAP customers to plan how they will adapt and optimize legacy job scheduling processes as they move ERP workloads into a RISE environment.

Challenges adapting job scheduling workflows in RISE

When organizations move from an on-premises ERP system like SAP ECC to RISE with SAP, one often overlooked challenge is the shift in how job scheduling workflows are handled.

In ECC on-premises, it’s common to install third-party scheduling agents directly on application servers or to use operating system (OS)–level scripts, such as shell scripts or cron jobs, to trigger file transfers and background jobs. However, in RISE, these approaches are not permitted.

In most cases, SAP ECS prohibits customers from installing third-party software directly on managed application servers or executing OS-level scripts. While these RISE controls ensure standardization, security and compliance in the managed cloud environment, they also mean customers must rethink how they orchestrate job scheduling workflows and setup. Workflows that once relied on direct OS scripting, like file movements or event triggers, require new methods and infrastructure in RISE. As a result, customers need a compliant, standardized way to handle these operations without compromising control, performance or visibility.

How SAP ECS supports the transition: Managed services for RunMyJobs

RunMyJobs managed services, delivered by the SAP ECS team, offer a compliant and lower-risk approach to modernizing job scheduling within a RISE environment. Rather than relying on OS-level scripts or unmanaged third-party agents installed without oversight and control on application servers, SAP ECS provides managed connectivity and oversight for RunMyJobs. This enables customers to execute OS-level workflows, including file transfers, in a standardized, cloud-compliant way.

 

Because these services are managed directly by SAP ECS and operate in the managed RISE architecture, customers retain the flexibility and reliability they had on-premises — without violating access restrictions or compromising compliance. RunMyJobs effectively bridges the gap between traditional, on-premises scheduling methods and the controlled, secure operating environment that RISE delivers.

 

Through the ECS-managed RunMyJobs service layer, SAP ensures its customers can automate end-to-end processes — for example, scripts that involve file transfers — securely and efficiently without developing custom workarounds or deploying unsupported software. 

 

RunMyJobs services available in the SAP ECS portfolio

RunMyJobs is the only Service Orchestration and Automation Platform (SOAP), workload automation or other third-party job scheduling solution included in the RISE with SAP reference architecture. The following managed services, available through SAP ECS, provide a standardized foundation for customers migrating scheduling workloads into RISE.

 

These are defined in SAP’s Roles and Responsibilities Document and Service Description Documentation for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, delivered by SAP ECS — starting on line 1222.

RunMyJobs OS-Platform Agent installation

This platform agent is a lightweight piece of software installed at the OS level of the application servers within an ECS-managed environment. It acts as an execution engine, receiving instructions securely from the customer’s RunMyJobs tenant to perform OS-level jobs and local file transfers.

 

It provides a fully supported and secure method to automate OS-level scripts with file-based event triggers and file transfers on RISE application servers without complex, unapproved or customer-managed workarounds. As part of the managed service, ECS installs, configures and monitors the health of the RunMyJobs OS-Platform Agent on behalf of the customer.

Installation and configuration of the RunMyJobs Secure Gateway connection

SAP ECS installs the RunMyJobs Secure Gateway on a dedicated virtual machine and configures it for secure connectivity to the RISE environment. This gateway supports general job execution and workflow orchestration that do not require OS-level access or scripts. SAP ECS also monitors gateway health and manages connectivity troubleshooting as part of the service.

Additional advanced job management services

This application-level service enables proactive SAP process monitoring, triggered and executed via defined named jobs within the customer’s RunMyJobs tenant. SAP ECS monitors job execution, creates incident tickets for errors and performs technical remediation as defined in the service scope.

 

Note: These managed services do not include:

 

  • Scheduling or configuration of jobs and processes
  • Design or implementation of jobs and process definitions
  • Functional issue resolution

 

These activities remain the responsibility of the customer within their RunMyJobs tenant.

The strategic role of RunMyJobs in RISE with SAP

RunMyJobs is an SAP Endorsed App, Premium Certified and included in the RISE with SAP reference architecture through SAP ECS-managed services.

For customers planning or undergoing a RISE transformation, it’s essential to address legacy on-premises job scheduling early in the process. RunMyJobs provides a supported, compliant way to extend workload automation into the managed cloud. With SAP ECS-managed RunMyJobs services, customers can ensure operational continuity while running complex job scheduling and file movement scenarios securely within RISE.

Because it is both an Endorsed App and part of the RISE reference architecture, RunMyJobs with select managed services is the recommended solution — and one that many SAP customers have already implemented to bring their scheduling processes into the RISE landscape with the support of the SAP ECS team.

For more information on how the RunMyJobs by Redwood solution works with RISE with SAP, click here.

entry.title: Re: ChaRM - BOR BUS2000116 Delegate is not working for ac...
entry.content:
I found the issue by setting an external debug on the BOR program and opening  a change document. I discovered the Project_ID attribute's code was not being executed. So, the code for the SystemSid and SystemClient was not able to leverage the Project_ID when determining those fields. The code was adjusted to grab the Project_ID before trying to grab the SystemSid or SystemClient. Then the condition worked as expected. Here is a sample of the code to get the SystemSid:

" Get the Project System Name/SID using the Project ID (object-project_id)
get_property systemsid changing container.

------ INSERT ------

IF object-key-businessprocess IS NOT INITIAL.

DATA: lv_projectid TYPE /tmwflow/smi_project.
CLEAR: lv_projectid.
SELECT project_id
FROM ai_cm_bt_order_v UP TO 1 ROWS
INTO lv_projectid
WHERE guid = object-key-businessprocess.
ENDSELECT.

IF sy-subrc = 0 AND lv_projectid IS NOT INITIAL.
object-project_id = lv_projectid.
ELSE.
CLEAR lv_projectid.
ENDIF.

ENDIF.

------ END INSERT ------

IF object-project_id IS NOT INITIAL.

DATA: lv_systemsid TYPE diagls_tech_syst_long_sid.

CLEAR lv_systemsid.
SELECT src_sys_name
FROM /salm/cm_chgcycl UP TO 1 ROWS
INTO lv_systemsid
WHERE smi_project = object-project_id.
ENDSELECT.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
object-systemsid = lv_systemsid.
ELSE.
CLEAR lv_systemsid.
ENDIF.

ENDIF.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
swc_set_element container 'SystemSid' object-systemsid.
ENDIF.

end_property.

entry.title: Re: Requirement class for sales documents (Details)
entry.content:
Hello @chralb 

You can analyse Requirement Classes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud via Define Requirement Classes (SSCUI ID 105034) in Sales Configuration (Manage Your Solution).

In Public Cloud, requirement classes are SAP-delivered content for the MTO/MTS scenarios, such as the MTO classes used with the costing variant PPC4. You cannot create new requirement classes; therefore, there is no Define Requirements Classes SSCUI to edit them.  SAP Help Portal-Make-to-Order (MTO) Sales Order Costing

You can configure the mapping that determines the requirements type based on item category and MRP type. The activity is Determine Requirement Type by Item Category and MRP Type, listed as Configuration Activity ID 105120 in current releases. SAP Support Portal-3644534 - Requirement type not automatically determined on sales order creation

SAP provides guidance on how to verify the costing variant used in sales-order costing, like PPC4 and its valuation variant parameters. SAP Support Portal-3350673 - How to check Costing/Valuation Variants for Sales Costing

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: invocing Date Updation in Sales Order - Billing Docum...
entry.content:
Hello @GAK1 

In S/4HANA Cloud, public cloud, there is no ECC-style mass change for sales-order invoicing or billing-plan dates. The Mass Change of Sales Documents app only allows changes to a limited set of header and item fields; billing plan dates are not included, so it cannot be used for that purpose. SAP Help Portal-Mass Change of Sales Documents

What functions effectively at scale and is supported

Set the billing date when creating invoices; no need to change the SO. In Create Billing Documents, enable Billing Settings → Set billing date and type before billing and enter the date for extensive selections from the billing due list. App purpose/usage. SAP Help Portal-Create Billing Documents

SAP Support Portal-3232277 - Issue with Billing Date field in billing Fiori apps - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2208

Change the billing date on invoices (header FKDAT) using Change Billing Documents to mass-adjust the Billing Date, subject to restrictions such as the absence of an FI document. SAP Help Portal-Create Billing Documents

There is no standard mass UI for billing-plan dates on SOs. Technically, customers handle bulk updates via integration against the Sales Order (A2X) API; feasibility depends on which entities and fields your tenant release exposes. Review the API on SAP’s Accelerator Hub and test against a subset first. SAP Business Accelerator Hub

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Migrating SAP Work Manager from SAP Mobile Platform to Agentry Cloud Edition in BTP
entry.content:
Migrating SAP Work Manager and Inventory Manager applications from SAP Mobile Platform (SMP) to Agentry Cloud Edition (ACE) is essential to access the latest advancements and ensure continued support. This guide is for Work Manager 6.6 or later and Inventory Manager 4.4 or later. The migration involves steps similar to deploying a new ACE application, with some additional considerations.

Important Note: The mainstream maintenance for SMP 3.2 concludes on December 31, 2025. Transitioning to ACE ensures your applications remain supported and take advantage of continuous updates and enhancements.

 

Initial ACE Configuration

Begin by referring to the ACE Quickstart guide and follow the steps up to step 6. This will help you set up the basic configuration required for ACE.

Review existing application

ACE supports only the Java backend. Therefore, it's essential to review your existing Agentry application for any logic that relies on other backends. Any such logic will need to be removed or reworked to ensure compatibility with ACE.

Exporting and modifying application

Export your existing application to retain its current configurations and logic. Run the application installer for ACE to create the base installation package. Then, publish your Agentry application definitions to replace the base application logic. If you have extended the Java code, ensure you add your custom JAR files to the Java folder of the application.

Alternative for Low-Complexity Modifications

If the required modifications are minimal, consider using the base applications provided by Work Manager 6.6.1 or Inventory Manager 4.4 and implement any necessary changes directly in the ACE version of the application.

Publishing and deploying application

To configure your Agentry application, follow these instructions.
For configuring the SAP Work Manager application with SAP Mobile Services, please refer to these instructions.
Additionally, the following article is helpful for configuring Principal Propagation to ABAP System using RFC.

Setting up Java backend connection

Follow these instructions to configure Java Backend connection for your Agentry application with SAP Mobile Services.

Commercial Considerations

A commercial change is required to terminate the on-premise contract and migrate to the Work Manager Cloud Edition. Ensure that you work with your account representative to finalize this transition smoothly.

entry.title: Re: How to Add Value help from standard/Custom VH CDS vie...
entry.content:
Good day @Gahan_Narayan1 

Thank you for your question.

Yes, it is possible in public cloud to add a CDS-based value help to a field in a Custom Business object. Please note that the CDS view must be released for Value Help scenario. You can follow the following steps to achieve it:

  • Ensure your CDS (either standard or custom) is marked with the Scenario = Value Help and published.
  • Open your CBO, assign this CDS as the Value Help source for your target field.
  • Republish and test the Fiori app you generated. F4 help should now enable you to fetch entries from the CDS view.

If the value help option doesn’t appear in the CBO app, make use of Custom Fields and Logic app to attach it indirectly.

If you have an advanced use case e.g., conditional value help or multi-field dependency, I suggest you consider using the Developer Extensibility on SAP BTP ABAP Environment.

Have a look at the following references.

Custom Business Objects

Adding a Value Help with the Custom CDS Views App

S/4 Key User Extension - Complex value help for custom fields

Adding a Value Help with the Custom CDS Views App

Chris

entry.title: Re: Notification on Rejection of PR
entry.content:
Hello @Dinesh_158 

Thank you for your question.

The following references provide more details: Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions, Situation Handling & Process Purchase Requisitions

In summary, the PR creator does not receive an automatic rejection notification by default in public cloud. However, you can enable notification in two fully supported ways by:

  • Adding a Send Notification step to your Flexible Workflow and set the PR creator as the recipient.
  • Alternatively, you can configure a Situation Handling type to trigger when a PR is rejected, notifying the creator through Fiori in-app message or email.

Both methods work entirely within the public cloud extensibility framework, without custom coding or backend access.

Below are steps you can carry out 

  • Open the Manage Situation Type- Extended App.

  • Search for or create a custom situation using available template: MM_PUR_PR_APPROVAL_REJECTED

Then define:

  • Trigger Condition: PR Status = Rejected
  • Recipient Determination: Purchase Requisition creator
  • Channel: In-App Notification or Email

Then activate the situation type.

This gives the requestor a notification bell alert in Fiori Launchpad or an optional email, complaint with SAP Public Cloud governance.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: TRM Released Indicator set as Blocked
entry.content:
Hello @ktemma 

Why variable-rate loans show “Blocked”
For variable interest, flows stay blocked until the coupon is fixed. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you need to perform an Interest Rate Adjustment or Fixing using a valid reference interest rate on the fixing date. Without this, the system cannot calculate the amount, and flows cannot be released or posted. SAP Help Portal-Interest Rate Adjustment

Steps to unblock (post) the flows in sequence.

Verify that market data exists for the fixing date (your reference rate: SOFR/EURIBOR, etc.). If the rate is absent for that specific fixing date, the adjustment will not be calculated..SAP Help Portal-Reference Interest Rate Value

Execute the Interest Rate Adjustment for the transaction (manual or automatic options are available in Public Cloud). This action sets the coupon for the period. SAP Help Portal-Process Adjustments Manually - Interest Rates/FX Rates

Release cash flows once amounts are determined. Use the Release Cash Flows Fiori app if you are using the standard review/release step.

Common pitfalls to check

No/incorrect reset rule or fixing date in the condition set → maintain the adjustment frequency and fixing date rule so the system knows when to fix. SAP Help Portal-Interest Rate Adjustment

Calendar and holiday shift moves the fixing date to a day without a rate; ensure market data covers the actual adjusted fixing date. SAP Support Portal-3659566 - Interest Rate Dates adjustment based on multiple calendars in Transaction Management - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Note: Classic guides reference TI10/TJ05; in Public Cloud, fixing is done through Fiori adjustment apps, following the same principle: the rate must be fixed before release or posting. SAP Help Portal-Process Adjustments Manually - Interest Rates/FX Rates

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Second Half 2025 Release: Continued innovations in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (ECP)
entry.content:
Hello Everyone!

Following the groundbreaking innovations in Business AI and automation from our 1H2025 release (read the blog here), we’re thrilled to unveil the new capabilities in the second half 2025 release of SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (ECP). Below are the key highlights, but be sure to explore the What's New Viewer for the complete release notes and full details on everything we’re delivering.

AI-enabled “Explain my pay statement” comes to Germany, Netherlands and Mexico

In this release, we’re expanding the AI-enabled "Explain my pay statement" feature to Germany, the Netherlands, and Mexico, following its successful launch in the USA, UK, and Australia in 1H2025. This expansion includes support for German, Dutch, and Spanish languages, in addition to English. With this feature, employees can effortlessly understand their pay statements by asking Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, questions like, “Compare my historical pay statements” or “Explain a specific deduction.” This reduces HR inquiries and tickets by up to 50% in some cases, while significantly boosting employee satisfaction. Joule’s responses are tailored to the company’s policy documents for accurate, personalized insights.

For more information on this feature see the “What’s New Viewer”


[Screenshot] ‘Explain my pay statement’ feature now supports Mexico in Spanish language: Prompt “Explain my deductions”

Addition of ad-hoc off cycle application to the Enhanced Payroll Control Center (PCC)

The addition of ad-hoc off-cycle application in the Enhanced Payroll Control Center (released in 1H2025) fills the gap in payroll processing by enabling the non-routine adjustments (e.g., Bonuses, corrections, etc.) outside the standard cycles. This allows running the payroll calculations and making adjustments at any time. This is particularly useful for addressing urgent issues such as missed payments, corrections to employee data, or unforeseen expenses that need immediate attention. With the addition of this capability, the enhanced PCC handles the payroll scenarios end-to-end.

For more information on this feature see the “What’s New Viewer”

[Screenshot] Adhoc Off-cycle application in the Enhanced Payroll Control Center (PCC) 

Enhanced Payroll Information in the new People Profile (PPX)

We are enhancing the visibility of payroll-related information in the updated People Profile, which allows users to quickly locate specific details, enhancing efficiency and reducing clutter.  Each configured category within the payroll information section will now be presented individually as a separate card within the People Profile. Also, the payroll administrators will get information to the last replication status of employee master data, ensuring up-to-date and accurate information.

For more information on this feature see the “What’s New Viewer”


[Screenshot] Enhanced payroll information in the new People Profile (PPX) 

What else is new in this release?

There are a number of additional innovations available for SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll in the second half 2025 release, including

  • Custom Filters Supported on the Complete Payroll Tasks Page
  • Enable employees to access their inactive employment data
  • Alumni access to restricted payroll information
  • And more

See the "What's New Viewer" for more information on these features.

Where can I find more information?

Here are additional resources for those interested in learning more about SAP Payroll solutions

  • SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll Website
  • SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll SAP Help (Implementation) (Requires ID)
  • SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll Community Page (Discussion Forum) (Requires ID)
  • SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll Learning Journey (Educational Content) (Requires SAP Lea...
  • Other recent release highlights for SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll
    • 1H/2025 Release Highlight Blog
    • 2H/2024 Release Highlight Blog
    • 1H/2024 Release Highlight Blog
    • 2H/2023 Release Highlight Blog

For information on release highlights across SAP SuccessFactors HCM, visit this one stop shop for all product release and road map information

entry.title: EWA設定に関するDAAの要件確認
entry.content:
ご担当者様


いつもお世話になっております。
Sharp株式会社、BASIS担当のイエンと申します。


現在、弊社のシステム「K0U」に対し、SAP Solution Manager (SolMan) を利用したEarlyWatch Alert (PERSON_NAME) レポートの出力設定を進めております。この設定に関して、Diagnostic Agent (DAA) の取り扱いについていくつか確認させていただきたい事項がございます。


つきましては、お手数をおかけしますが、以下の点についてご教示いただけますでしょうか。



1.管理対象システムがABAPシステムである場合、PERSON_NAMEレポート出力のみを目的とするのであれば、Diagnostic Agent (DAA) のインストールは必須ではないという認識でよろしいでしょうか。


2.DAAのインストールが必要な場合、監視対象となるSAPインスタンスが稼働する全ての物理/仮想サーバー（ホスト）ごとにDAAをインストールする必要があるという認識でよろしいでしょうか。


3.DAAのインストールが必須となるサーバーに紐づくインスタンスについて、具体的にどの種類のインスタンスが該当するのか、定義をご教示いただけますでしょうか。


4.PERSON_NAMEレポート出力への影響：
もし複数のサーバーが存在する環境において、一部のサーバーにDAAをインストールし、別のサーバーには未インストールの状態とした場合、PERSON_NAMEレポートの出力内容にどのような変化や影響が生じるかをご教示ください。K0Uシステムの現在のSolManの設定画面のスクリーンショットを本メールに添付しておりますので、合わせてご確認いただけますと幸いです。


お忙しいところ恐縮ですが、ご回答をお待ちしております。


何卒よろしくお願い申し上げます。


Sharp株式会社
BASIS担当 イエン


--- Support Assistant ---
Managed System Configuration
Errors during Managed System Configuration
Issues in "Assign Diagnostics Agent"
Installing the Diagnostics Agent


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: EWA設定に関するDAAの要件確認
entry.content:
ご管理者様

平素は大変お世話になっております。

EWAレポートに関する質問について、下記回答をご参照ください。

1.管理対象システムがABAPシステムである場合、DAAがEWAレポートの生成に影響していません。DAAはEWAレポートに出力される内容に関する監視データを収集しています。

EWAレポートに正確的な内容を表示させるため、DAAのインストールが強く推奨されます。

2.DAAのインストールがホストごとに必要となります。

3.対象システムタイプにかかわらず、監視対象システムが存在するホストごとに、DAAのインストールが必要になります。

4.EWAレポート出力への影響：

もし複数のサーバーが存在する環境において、一部のサーバーにDAAをインストールし、別のサーバーには未インストールの状態とした場合、収集される監視データが不完全となる可能性が存在するため、EWAレポートに表示されるデータの正しさが疑われます。
恐れ入りますが、ご了承のほどよろしくお願いします。

以上、よろしくお願いします。
Haterm
SAPサポート

entry.title: Need to know the procedure to be followed to convert the connection from HTTP to HTTPS
entry.content:
currently FRUN configuration from FRUN to Managed system through HTTPsince the HTTP connection is planning to restricted planning to migrate all HTTP connection to HTTPS.Need to know the procedure to be followed to convert the connection from HTTP to HTTPSLet us know what are the further details required


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Need to know the procedure to be followed to convert...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

I have outlined the necessary steps to convert the FRUN to managed system communication using HTTPS. Below are the details for your reference:

  1. Enable the SAP Host Agent SSL.
    -> Responsible team: BC-CCM-HAG.
    -> Refer to the following resources for guidance:
         SSL Configuration for the SAP Host Agent | SAP Help Portal
         2662416 - SAP Host Agent - automatic setup of self-signed standard SSL server PSE

  2. Enable the Managed System SSL.
    -> Responsible team: BC-SEC-SSF for ABAP and BC-JAS-SEC for the JAVA.
    -> For ABAP:
         2970934 - How to create the CSR and how to import the certificate response for ABAP system
         https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/e73bba71770e4c0ca5fb2a3c17e8e229/4923501ebf5a1902e10000000a42189c.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST
    ->  For JAVA:
          1770585 - How to configure SSL on the AS Java

  3. Enable the SSL communication from FRUN to the SAP Host Agent.
    -> Follow the steps outlined in KBA 3203198 How TLS/SSL communication works from SDA to FRUN.

  4. Send the latest Managed System info to the FRUN LMDB.
    Ensure the HTTPS ports are visible in LMDB under Technical Instances. This is a prerequisite for the next step.
  5. Update the SSI Configuration.
    In the SSI Edit Configuration->Communication Mode->select the HTTPS related options. 

Basically, these are the steps for your requirement. 

Best regards,
Vera Jiang
SAP Support

entry.title: Super task list for production routing
entry.content:
Business context

In production planning, depending on the business complexity, the amount of master data can increase and be difficult to manage. Sometimes we face very similar products that double the quantity of master data due to one specific difference between them. In a scenario where the materials are classified using advanced variant configuration, the Super Task List functionality helps with this. When used together with Advanced Variant Configuration tools, it makes routing easier and allows one master data object to support different materials in a flexible way

The main idea of the Super Task List for the configurable material is to aggregate all possible production operations into a single task list master data and use material characteristics as the driver to filter which operation is applicable for each characteristic value

To make this functionality way of working easier to understand, let’s use the classic forklift example often shown in SAP demonstrations.
In our fictitious forklift process, we have a total of five work centers. The first one represents a general assembly that is always used, while the other four are called only for specific product characteristics.

 

Step 1 – Create the Super Task List

The first step is to create the Super Task List with all possible operations and assign the configurable material to it.

Step 2 – Define the characteristics

The next step is to prepare the characteristics that will drive the task list decisions. In this example, the following characteristics were created:

Characteristic namePossible values
AVC_ENGINE_TYPECombustion or Electric
AVC_LOAD_CAPACITY2 tons or 5 tons
AVC_MAST_HEIGHT        Standard or Extra-high

These characteristics were then assigned to a specific class for easier management:

Step 3 – Model the rules

The next step is to model the rules that will be applied in the Super Task List.
Using the Variant Configuration (VC) modeling environment, open the configurable material to check all assigned objects. In the routing details, object dependencies can be inserted for each operation.
In this example, the dependencies SELECT_WC_B, SELECT_WC_C, SELECT_WC_D, and SELECT_WC_E were created.

These dependencies are of the type ‘selection condition’. The syntax is simple:
Characteristic name = 'specific value'
If the condition is true, the operation is selected. Otherwise, it is not.

The following selection conditions were created:

  • Electric Engine Station (WC_B): Selected only if AVC_ENGINE_TYPE = 'Electric'
  • Combustion Engine Station (WC_C): Selected only if AVC_ENGINE_TYPE = 'Combustion'
  • Structural reinforcement (WC_D): Selected only if AVC_LOAD_CAPACITY = 5 tons
  • Structural reinforcement (WC_E): Selected only if AVC_MAST_HEIGHT = 'Extra-high'

Note: Structural assembly (WC_A) has no object dependency. It is a default operation, always selected

Step 4 – Test with simulator

Using the VC simulation tool, it is possible to test the results of the parameters created.

If no special values are entered, only the default operation is chosen.

If AVC_ENGINE_TYPE = 'Combustion', the combustion engine station is added.

If AVC_ENGINE_TYPE = 'Electric', the electric engine station is selected instead of Combustion engine station.

As more characteristics are populated, additional operations are included in the task list according to the selection conditions.

Conclusion

When the business process is well defined and the characteristic rules are properly modeled, the Super Task List becomes a powerful tool. It reduces the complexity of production master data, ensures flexibility in routing, and provides better control over manufacturing processes

References

SAP course: S4105 / Variant Configuration (with AVC) in SAP S/4HANA

SAPHelp: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f369b2eff700401494ba6e7c9a573288/2b05cc19bc0746e2a8c60469e0c1ccc0.html

entry.title: BexWeb to SAC Data Analyzer: How to Execute, What to Know, and Why It’s a Strategic Opportunity
entry.content:
BexWeb to SAC Data Analyzer: How to Execute, What to Know, and Why It’s a Strategic Opportunity

With SAP ending support for BexWeb Tools in 2030, companies and users are being “encouraged” to transition to more modern SAP solutions. For organizations that have relied on BexWeb for reporting, this presents a unique opportunity to elevate their reporting capabilities to the next level and future-proof them by moving to the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and its integrated Data Analyzer (DA).

 

Why migrate to the Data Analyzer

Modern, Intuitive User Interface

One of the most immediately noticeable advantages of migrating to Data Analyzer is the modern, responsive, and clean user interface. This design benefits both report creators and report consumers, making interaction smoother and more intuitive. Beyond aesthetics, SAC introduces modern navigation and control concepts that align with contemporary web design principles, allowing users to adopt the platform quickly and work more efficiently.

Seamless Integration with the SAP Business Data Cloud

Perhaps the biggest advantage of moving from BexWeb to the SAC Data Analyzer is the seamless integration into the SAP Business Data Cloud. This “automatic” connectivity enables effortless interaction with other SAP cloud solutions and direct integration within SAC itself. Rather than performing a simple one-to-one migration from BexWeb to Data Analyzer, organizations gain a unified, enterprise-wide reporting environment. This integration unlocks synergies with existing stories, scripting capabilities, and overall corporate analytics workflows.

Access to New Features

SAC introduces a wide range of modern features that enhance reporting, analytics, and data visualization. Users benefit from more flexible, interactive, and efficient workflows, gaining advanced tools to extract deeper insights and make data-driven decisions. Features such as Auto-Refresh, Fullscreen Mode, Table Copy-Paste, and Table Freeze simplify working with complex datasets, reduce interruptions, and provide a smoother, more flexible analysis experience compared to legacy tools.

Long-Term Support and Continuous Development

With SAP ending support for BexWeb Analyzer in 2030, migrating becomes a practical necessity. Beyond this, SAC serves as a cornerstone of SAP’s cloud strategy and, along with the SAC Data Analyzer, benefits from long-term support and ongoing development. SAP’s roadmap shows continuous improvements and new features, ensuring that migration not only preserves existing strengths but also opens the door to future enhancements and innovations.

 

Key Features of the Data Analyzer

The SAP Analytics Cloud Data Analyzer (DA) is designed to enable users to explore and manipulate data in a detailed, table-based format. It provides a variety of tools for controlling, formatting, and interacting with data, making reporting more flexible, efficient, and insightful. The features can be grouped into three main categories: Table Structure (“Builder”), Formatting (“Styler”), and Functionality.

Table Structure (“Builder”)

The table structure in DA consists of three main components: rows, columns, and filters. These components can be populated with dimensions and measures (note: measures filtering is currently not supported in Live Connections—see “Limitations of the Data Analyzer”).

The SAC Data Analyzer allows users to manipulate all parts of the table directly within SAC, provided the required data is loaded from BW and no static filters are applied. Key capabilities include:

  • Rearranging rows, columns, and filters to create custom views.
  • Performing ad hoc changes such as calculations on measures to enhance insights.

Unlike SAC Stories, only ad hoc calculations are supported; ad hoc restrictions or aggregations are not currently available. Overall, the Data Analyzer enables full manipulation of the table, allowing users to generate a comprehensive, flexible and detailed view of their data.

Formatting („Styler“)

DA provides several options to format tables and tailor their visual appearance to user needs:

  • Table Properties: Control overall layout (currently limited beyond default settings).
  • Number Format: Adjust measure display, including scale, unit, decimal places, and sign.
  • Conditional Formatting: Highlight values that meet specific conditions, enabling users to quickly identify important metrics.

These features help make data easier to read and interpret, improving the efficiency of reporting and analysis.

Functionality

Beyond table display and formatting, the Data Analyzer offers several advanced functionalities:

  • Bookmarks: Save customized table views that deviate from the standard query structure and formatting.
  • Broadcasting & Scheduling: Share data directly via links, or export to Excel, PDF, or CSV. Scheduled distributions are also supported.
  • Interactive Features: Filter or exclude entries, use in-cell charts, toggle auto-refresh, and interact directly with table data.
  • Navigation: Use Context Menus opened by right click for fast manipulation of the Table view
  • Report Integration: Connect Data Analyzer tables with other reports via the Report-Report Interface.

These functionalities allow users not only to view and format data but also to actively manage, share, and integrate it into broader reporting workflows, making DA a dynamic and versatile analytical tool.

 

Limitations of the Data Analyzer

After years of development and updates, the SAC Data Analyzer has become a powerful tool that fulfills many reporting requirements. However, some limitations remain in its current feature set. It’s important to note that some of these gaps may not exist when using SAC Stories instead of Data Analyzer or both as them im combination.

Report-Report-Interface (=RRI)

The Report-Report Interface allows users to create navigational jumps to other reports directly within a query using the BW transaction RSBBS. When this query is opened in a Story or in DA, the jump works without additional development effort. Current SAC capabilities, however, only support jumps to:

  • Queries (opened in DA)
  • SAP Transactions
  • URLs

Passing parameters to other SAC dashboards is not supported because URLs do not transmit parameters by default. This limits seamless navigation and parameter-driven interactions across dashboards. However this can be achieved by using Business Add-Ins in the Business Warehouse, needing additional resources.

Exceptions & Conditions

Similar to BexWeb, DA offers conditional formatting through thresholds, allowing users to highlight values based on static or dynamic Measures values and, if needed, dimensions. Users can also apply ranking to filter for top or bottom X values of a selected Measures. Whereas Filters on Measures themselves are currently not possible, unlike BexWeb. For example, filtering all Measures values below a certain threshold is only available for import models, not Live Connections. This reduces flexibility for advanced conditional analysis directly in Data Analyzer.

Formatting

While DA meets core formatting needs, including number formatting, conditional formatting, and pre-built templates for row separation, it lacks some visual customization options compared to SAC Stories, for example:

  • No branding options (e.g., adding headers or corporate identity elements).
  • Limited table appearance customization, which could enhance usability and visual appeal.

Although these limitations do not prevent core functionality, they represent areas where the user experience could be further improved.

Scripting & Miscellaneous

Currently, DA does not support scripting, unlike SAC Stories. This restricts the ability to implement dynamic, complex logic or custom functionality within the table itself. As a result, Tables remain mostly static and cannot be dynamically manipulated within SAC beyond built-in features. In addition “Minor issues” also exist, such as small navigation quirks or differences compared to BexWeb, which may require workarounds. Despite these limitations, the SAC Data Analyzer remains a powerful tool, but users should be aware of its current boundaries when planning migrations or advanced reporting scenarios.

 

Migration and what you need to know

When migrating from BexWeb to SAP Analytics Cloud, there are three key questions to consider, in this order:

  1. What will be migrated?
  2. Which Live Connection is required?
  3. Which migration method is most suitable?

This chapter will explain the different migration options, their recommended use cases. The following chapter will provide concrete examples of how a migration might look in practice.

What Will Be Migrated?

The first question is: “What do I want to migrate?” Different use cases exist depending on how data is currently managed in BexWeb. The most common scenarios include:

  • Classic Reporting: Standard query views
  • Bookmarks: Customized views or modifications of queries
  • Scheduling of Publications: Automated distribution of queries or bookmarks
  • Templates: including Groupings of dimensions

Once the elements to migrate are determined, the next step is selecting the appropriate Live Connection.

Which Live-Connection is required?

Assuming that all BexWeb data comes from a SAP BW, the next consideration is which type of Live Connection to use:

  • Live Connection with Model
  • Live Connection without Model

The difference is that a Live Connection with a Model accesses an SAC artifact with a live BW connection, while a Live Connection without a Model connects directly to BW.

Live Connection with Model:

  • Enables the creation of more complex reports (e.g., Stories)
  • Allows additional manipulation and authorization of data within SAC
  • Recommended if corporate standards require it or if future Story migration is anticipated

Live Connection without Model:

  • Eliminates the need for an additional SAC artifact and reduces maintenance effort (e.g., transport management)
  • Simpler and faster to implementation
  • Recommended if no additional functionality or corporate requirements exist

Which Migration Method is Suitable?

Migration options depend largely on what is being migrated. Migrating from BexWEb offers four primary migration types:

  • Simple Link
    • Opens a direct live connection to a query or model in the Data Analyzer
    • Always displays data in the default view
  • Shortcut
    • Opens DA in a specific variant without creating an SAC artifact
    • Deviations in format and content are stored in the shortcut (similar to BexWeb bookmarks)
    • May be temporary depending on system settings
  • Insight
    • Refers to a saved DA artifact called an Insight
    • Stores deviations from the default view and allows further changes without altering the link
    • Allows Scheduling
    • Allows deviations saved without overriding the original Insight
  • Story
    • Refers to a saved SAC Story artifact
    • Utilizing all features by using a Story, in exchange for higher effort in migrating and maintaining

Recommendations by Use Case

Templates:

  • Templates no longer exist in DA; only dimension groupings can be migrated
  • If specific groupings are needed, a Live Connection with Model is required
  • After creating the model, the BexWeb report can be migrated as Classic Reporting, Bookmark, or Scheduling, depending on requirements

Bookmarks:

  • Can be migrated via Shortcut, Insight, or Story as they save deviations
  • Story migration is usually not worth the effort for single bookmarks
  • If maintaining the SAC artifact for future updates is necessary, use Insight; otherwise, Shortcut is recommended as its simpler
  • If Exit-Variable need to be overridden in Bookmarks, only Insight can do so

Scheduling of Publications:

  • Scheduling is only possible with SAC artifacts
  • The only practical option for automated broadcasting is Insight migration
  • Story migration could theoretically work but is usually excessive for this purpose

Classic Reporting:

  • Usually migrated as Simple Link, the simplest and most direct method
  • If additional views or customized presentations are required, migrate as Bookmark
  • If advanced features (charts, scripting, or integration with other data) are needed, consider Story migration

 

How to Migrate from BexWeb to the Data Analyzer

Live Connection Setup

Step 1: Acquire the Query

  • Copy the relevant query from BexWeb (e.g., from the BexWeb URL or query library).

Step 2: Create a New Data Analyzer (DA)

With Model:

  1. Click “From an Existing Model”
  2. Search for the model in the directory or search menu
  3. Select the correct model

Without Model:

  1. Click “From a Data Source”
  2. Select the correct System Type and Connection
  3. Copy the query into the Search field
  4. Select the correct query from the search results
  5. Click OK

Alternative: Use a placeholder DA and adjust the query in the URL parameter dataSourceName.

Step 3: The DA opens as a live connection, granting access to the query.

 

Migration Process

Step 1: Obtain access to the query through DA.

Step 2: Select the migration option:

  • Simple Link
  • Shortcut
  • Insight
  • Story

Step 3: Make any necessary adjustments to the view.

Step 4: Depending on the chosen migration type:

  • Simple Link: Skip this step
  • Shortcut: Generate the shortcut via the Share context menu
  • Insight: Save using the Save context menu
  • Story: Create a new story

Step 5: Copy the newly generated URL.

Step 6: Replace the current BexWeb link with the new DA link.

Step 7: Migration is complete.

 

Example: Migrating a BexWeb Bookmark

Step 1: Preparation

  • What is being migrated? BexWeb Bookmark
  • Which Live Connection is needed? Without Model (no additional architecture layer required)
  • Which migration method? Shortcut (Bookmark-specific, Insight benefits not required)

Step 2: Obtain Access to Query

  • Copy the query from BexWeb (needed for the Bookmark)
  • Open DA from Data Source and paste the copied query

Step 3: Adjust the View

  • Data: Check rows, columns, measures, filters, variables (prompts), and ad hoc calculations
  • Formatting: Verify template, number format, and thresholds

Step 4: Generate Shortcut

  1. Click Share
  2. Click Create Shortcut Link
  3. Copy the generated shortcut URL

Step 5: Update all existing BexWeb links with the new Data Analyzer shortcut link

Step 6: Migration is complete

 

Roadmap & Outlook

Current SAC Data Analyzer Roadmap: https://roadmaps.sap.com/board?PRODUCT=67838200100800006884&BC=6EAE8B27FCC11ED892E91CE972E900CC&range=CURRENT-LAST#Q4%202025

The SAP Analytics Cloud and specifically its integrated Data Analyzer, has evolved into a product that is not only a capable successor to BexWeb but also offers new approaches, practical features, and migration opportunities that enable companies to not just preserve their reporting capabilities, but actively enhance them.

Thanks to its seamless integration with the SAP Business Data Cloud and ongoing product improvements, the Data Analyzer positions organizations to unlock even greater value from their reporting processes. With these innovations, the future holds significant potential for more advanced, efficient, and insightful analytics.
